results.title: Could Theatrical Movies Shut Out Streamers for the Top Oscars?
results.abstract: A year after Apple’s historic best-picture win, the lead categories could be filled entirely by big-screen films. But don’t call it a comeback just yet.
des_facet: Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths (Movie)

results.title: Stream These Three Great Documentaries
results.abstract: This month’s picks include an experimental film on border crossings, a tribute to a wildlife explorer and a chronicle of a civil rights leader.

results.title: How ‘Black Panther’ Builds Complex Characters From the Politics of Colonization
results.abstract: In the original and in “Wakanda Forever,” heroes and villains are deeply layered, reflecting real-life issues facing people of color around the world.

multimedia.caption: From left, Michaela Coel and Florence Kasumba are soldiers in “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.”
From left, Michaela Coel and Florence Kasumba are soldiers in “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.”

results.title: ‘Everything Everywhere’ Takes Top Prize at the Gotham Awards
results.abstract: The film’s Ke Huy Quan also won the supporting-performance trophy at the season’s first big ceremony, where honoree Adam Sandler brought down the house.

multimedia.caption: Ke Huy Quan with his Gotham Award on Monday night.

results.title: Israeli Filmmaker’s Critique of Popular Bollywood Film Draws Fierce Backlash
results.abstract: The filmmaker, Nadav Lapid, criticized “The Kashmir Files,” a Hindi-language film that depicts a violent chapter in the restive region of Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir.
results.byline: By Emily Schmall and Hari Kumar

multimedia.caption: Nadav Lapid during the 74th Cannes Film Festival in France in 2021.

results.abstract: This month’s picks include movies about an alien best friend, zombies with a strong sense of smell and lab-created superwomen.

results.title: Lars von Trier Had the Key to the End of ‘The Kingdom’ All Along
results.abstract: As he grapples with Parkinson’s and considers what’s next, the director continues to provoke in “The Kingdom Exodus,” the final season of his haunted-hospital drama.

multimedia.caption: Lars von Trier during production of “The Kingdom Exodus.” He learned he has Parkinson’s while shooting was underway and has since said he is taking a break from filmmaking.
Lars von Trier during production of “The Kingdom Exodus.” He learned he has Parkinson’s while shooting was underway and has since said he is taking a break from filmmaking.
Lars von Trier during production of “The Kingdom Exodus.” He learned he has Parkinson’s while shooting was underway and has since said he is taking a break from filmmaking.

results.title: ‘Avatar’ and the Mystery of the Vanishing Blockbuster
results.abstract: It was the highest-grossing film in history, but for years it was remembered mainly for having been forgotten. Why?

results.title: ‘Ainbo’ Review: Saved by a Princess
results.abstract: The eponymous young huntress of this animated feature forges a plan to protect her village in the Amazon rainforest.

results.title: The Cast and Crew of ‘Women Talking’ Reunite Over Mushroom Risotto
results.abstract: The actor Claire Foy, the filmmaker Sarah Polley and others involved with the film, out this month, gathered a year after shooting for a meal at Lincoln Center.

multimedia.caption: From left: Sheila McCarthy, Kate Hallett, Michelle McLeod, Sarah Polley, Claire Foy, Liv McNeil, Dede Gardner and Judith Ivey, photographed on Oct. 10, 2022, at Lincoln Ristorante on the Upper West Side, Manhattan.

results.title: Is It Toxic to Tell Everyone to Get Therapy?
results.abstract: It has become a social credential to be in therapy. It’s also incredibly difficult to access.

results.title: Plastic Off the Sofa
results.abstract: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” doesn’t shy away from big subjects like grief and colonization. The hosts of “Still Processing” are ready for it.

results.title: Irene Cara, ‘Fame’ and ‘Flashdance’ Singer, Dies at 63
results.abstract: Ms. Cara was a child star from the Bronx who gained fame in the 1980s as a singer of pop anthems and as the star of the movie “Fame.”
results.byline: By Alex Traub and Amanda Holpuch

multimedia.caption: Irene Cara as Coco Hernandez performing in a scene from the 1980 movie “Fame.” A former child actor, dancer and singer, she was the voice behind two of the biggest movie theme songs of the 1980s.
Irene Cara as Coco Hernandez performing in a scene from the 1980 movie “Fame.” A former child actor, dancer and singer, she was the voice behind two of the biggest movie theme songs of the 1980s.
Irene Cara as Coco Hernandez performing in a scene from the 1980 movie “Fame.” A former child actor, dancer and singer, she was the voice behind two of the biggest movie theme songs of the 1980s.

results.title: Jean-Marie Straub, Uncompromising Filmmaker, Is Dead at 89
results.abstract: Emerging from the French New Wave, driven by artistic purity, he and his wife and directing partner, Danièle Huillet, didn’t care if audiences walked out on their films.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Marie Straub in 1984. He emerged in the 1950s from the same circle of revolutionary French filmmakers as Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, a friend and neighbor.
Jean-Marie Straub in 1984. He emerged in the 1950s from the same circle of revolutionary French filmmakers as Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, a friend and neighbor.
Jean-Marie Straub in 1984. He emerged in the 1950s from the same circle of revolutionary French filmmakers as Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, a friend and neighbor.

results.title: The Importance of ‘Mr. Baseball’
results.abstract: Thirty years ago, a Tom Selleck comedy introduced Americans to Japanese baseball. It remains a go-to resource for foreign players.

results.title: ‘The Noel Diary’ Review: Revelations on a Cold Winter’s Night
results.abstract: Justin Hartley (“This Is Us”) is no stranger to the themes in this holiday romance, while Barrett Doss (“Station 19”) brings nuanced comedic timing and charm.

results.title: ‘The Corridors of Power’ Review: The Human Cost of Foreign Policy
results.abstract: This documentary illuminates America’s ever-shifting approach to conflicts abroad and how politics at home can even lead to inaction.

results.title: ‘White Noise’ Review: Toxic Events, Airborne and Domestic
results.abstract: Noah Baumbach’s adaptation of the Don DeLillo novel is a campus comedy, a domestic drama and an allegory of contemporary American life.

results.title: Two Films Hit Theaters, but Netflix Remains Committed to Streaming
results.abstract: The company agreed to some exclusive theatrical distribution for “Glass Onion” and “Matilda the Musical,” but it’s not clear exhibitors will get much more.

results.title: ‘The Swimmers’ Review: Overcoming the Greatest Challenges

results.title: How Noah Baumbach Made ‘White Noise’ a Disaster Movie for Our Moment
results.abstract: When the world shut down in 2020, the filmmaker found solace in Don DeLillo’s supposedly unadaptable novel — and turned it into a film that speaks to our deepest fears.

results.title: ‘Nanny’ Review: A New Job That Swallows Her Life
results.abstract: Nikyatu Jusu’s new film, about a Senegalese woman who works as a babysitter in New York, plays like an immigration drama and a cruel labor farce.

results.title: ‘All the Beauty and the Bloodshed’ Review: Nan Goldin’s Art and Activism
results.abstract: A new documentary focuses on the photographer’s struggle with OxyContin and her protest against the art establishment that took money from its makers.
